title: Thoughts on Sion 5.8 Changes, suggestions from a diamond Sion Main.
body:
{{champion:14}} 
I've been playing Sion for the last few months on my main and smurf and I feel like sharing my thoughts after the recent changes.

The changes to his shield have made jungling with Sion incredibly difficult early on, with the lowered shield health at level 1 combined with the 3 second reactivation your shield can only take a single hit from a large enemy such as a buff and will then get popped by any small enemy, requiring very specific positioning and split second timing to absorb a hit and still detonate it, while the extra 1 second means that you can not activate the shield after a attack and still detonate it in time.

My suggestion is to increase the base value of the shield from the 64 or so you have starting out back to the original 84-90 HP at rank 1, while keeping the decreased scaling as items are built.
2.5 seconds on the shield would also let you detonate it in time on the faster enemies in the jungle combined with a Q stun.

Also, whatever happened to letting his ult continue if it was the killing blow?

> [{quoted}](name=Danielas Kitten,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=b2hknQcI,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-05-03T02:04:00.682+0000)
>
> Lol it was supposed to be a nerf...why do you wanna buff him again? He is strong as fuk.

I'll agree with this.
I honestly don't think the shield nerf did that much to jungle Sion.  It might make a big difference at your level of play, but down where I am the change is mostly just an annoyance.

A change to a champion should not be made to make them intentionally more clunky to play (looking at whoever the brilliant one was to do that to {{champion:84}} and {{champion:26}} ).  There's a difference between separating the bad from the good; Veigar mains love his E's new change (now), and Veigar "mains" hate it because it isn't a complete move trap without warning.  However, his E isn't any harder to land, it just is easier for your opponent to react.

If you're going to make a move harder to use, it needs to be on a champion to champion interaction basis, not for champion to minion interaction (looking at you whoever gutted {{champion:28}}).  I think an example of a good way to do this would be to hyperbuff GP's ultimate damage, but give it a audible global warning and a Pantheon like indicator before the cannonballs drop.

I wouldn't mind them nerfing Sion's shield's strength, but when you make it clunky to use properly, that's when issues arise.

Does the shield feel clunky to use?  I know it feels a bit different and I don't get to blow it up twice against red, but by no means does it feel clunkier than the rest of Sion's kit to me (nor when it had a 2 second timer).

It intentionally makes him clunkier to jungle.  In order to blow the shield up, you have to activate it long before you start the camps (instead of about 0.75 seconds before the nerf).  The thing about Sion is that if you fail to do that, he loses a crapton of damage in jungle clears, as well as health from the extra time you need to clear the camps.  No other champion do you get punished as hard as Sion does for screwing up a jungle clear (except Eve, but she's a complete mess, not just clunkified like Sion and Zilean are.)

How does activating an ability earlier count as being clunky?  To me that's just planning.

  I think we just have different definitions for clunkiness here.

I see so many comments about top lane Sion being ridiculously strong, but I just don't believe it.  Sion isn't the universal lane bully everyone wants to make him out to be.  He's actually quite vulnerable during the laning phase, but most people don't seem to understand how to abuse his weaknesses.  Let's compare Sion to Nasus: both infinitely scaling tanks.  Are you going to run just any champion pick into a Nasus?  No, you want to shut that shit down before it gets out of hand.  If you don't treat Sion the same way you treat Nasus, come 20 minutes into the game, you are going to have a monster on the loose tearing your team apart.  Who would have thought?!?!

If you buff up on Sion you will find: 
1. He telegraphs every intention through his actions
2. He starts the game with extremely low health as an immobile tank
3. He lacks sustain and will become mana-gated by spell usage

From here you have a few options: 
1. Pick a champion with superior all-in
2. Pick a champion with superior range and poke
3. Pick a champion with superior sustain

Protip: there are plenty champs who possess one or all three of those qualities.  Sion's match-ups go two ways: he can either get away with free farm or he cannot.  The catch is that if Sion can't beat the all-in, poke or sustain he has to whittle his opponent down from range using E to land Q's and W's or he has leave lane to roam and make plays somewhere else.  Give him two options: fight you for his farm or wait until you push it into his tower.  If he tries to contest, pressure him from the side and work him into the all-in that he can't survive.  He won't escape with his life unless you run out of lane, he burns flash or his jungler comes to save him.  If he roams, push his towers down and pick on him in team engagements before he's tanky enough to handle it.  

For those of you willfully determined to farm behind of or in the middle of the minion wave, Sion will land his combo and fuck you up good.  Don't sit there patiently asking for an empowered E to the face.  On top of that obvious counter-play, Riot mana-gated the shit out of his poke in one of the recent patches.  If he tries to poke you down on his terms and you avoid any number of Q's, W's or E's then his mana bar won't allow him remain a threat.  My last piece of advice: Sion players are gullible and most of them don't have the self-control or patience to properly engage.  He will blow R at the whisper of an opportunity to finish someone off or engage a team-fight.  Side-step the R and kite him to death.  Even better if it's under your tower.  If he left his team, then dive his carries because he won't be in any position to protect them.  If you can't do any of these things, then you didn't pick the right team composition and you probably should've dodged.  

This is all so mind-blowing, I know.  Truly ground-breaking information.  No, I'm kidding.  These are simple strategies that take basic skills to execute.  Never forget: the number one rule to fighting Sion is listen to Sion.  He will tell you what he is doing as he yells at the top of his lungs, stands still to channel his axe smash or shouts angrily in your general direction.  Sion is literally the definition of counter-play and if you guys couldn't figure it out before they gutted him, then I think League's worse off than I had previously thought.  
{{champion:14}} {{item:3070}}

Hey, we aren't all gullible.  :P

Other than that this is pretty spot on.  However, Sion does have good health sustain; you have to get him to waste his mana (which isn't that hard, just don't stand in his Q).

Hahaha, don't I know we aren't all gullible... all the time.  I'm speaking from experience here, by the way.  I remember when I first picked Sion up and I just couldn't help myself.  Bad players conditioned me to unload willy nilly, after awhile I finally reeled that in though.  But you are right about his health sustain, he does have some of the better base regen in the game and if he is getting farm, the stacks from his W passive do add up over time.  Although he doesn't really compete against real sustain threats like Vladimir or Swain.

I think that Riot should have chosen to make Sion's W scale up over the course of the game *or* have a longer reactivation time.

He'll survive the change, but his jungling was hit harder than it needed to be. If top lane Sion is the problem, Sion's nerfs shouldn't be so detrimental to his jungling.
That thing about his ult was never implemented, because while it was cool, it was REALLY overpowered in the testing they did, especially considering he was a very strong champ at the time.
